reviewText:
Particle Mace is a masterful lesson in game design that with its perfect scoring system and haunting beautiful abstract world will put you in some sort of hypnotic trance. While you leave your mind behind you, tracing circles like in a Sufi whirling dance ritual. One of the most captivating game experiences since Tetsuya Mizoguchi‚Äôs Rez, that gives a true meaning to the expression videogames as an art form
In my first 5 minutes with Particle Mace, I wasn‚Äôt so impressed. Sure, the main mechanic was original and a brilliant twist respect to the typical twin stick shooter. But I wasn‚Äôt able to understand why it was the favorite game for some of my most beloved friends. But after I spent half an hour with it, when I dominated its psychics mechanics and I understood its scoring system realizing the masterful and completely perfect game design behind it, I became anxious.

I felt my pulse accelerated with each heartbeat sending unconscious signals to my mind. Full of binary coded verses talking about the overwhelming sense of beauty suspended in the abstract and almost ethereal world behind Particle Mace.

It‚Äôs the same sense of accomplishment that you can feel when you meet for the first time a lifetime love, this person who you will spend some of your more pleasant and intimate moments. Sometimes this tempestuous love will induce you to obfuscation, making you to feel a bit dumb about yourself for every bad step taken in your relationship, this meteor that you stupidly crashed while you were concentrated trying to evade a pursuing enemy‚Äôs red ship. But then you reconcile with it and the previously induced rage only takes you to a next and much more passionate encounter in which you have a better understanding of every particle in its body, allowing you to achieve a higher score.

Sometimes, Particle Mace is a meditative experience that puts you in some sort of state of trance while you are tracing circles at a constant pace that flows like a mantra. An experience similar to a Sufi whirling dance ritual in which the participants are able to elevate his minds from his bodies through the constant act of swirling with the rhythm of the music.

At other times, Particle Mace turns into a fast pace and frantic arcade experience with the screen inundated with menacing objects floating in the vastness of space. And you feel inside of a space opera, while you maneuver your ship tracing impossible parables. Creating complex strategies to destroy the enemy ships, trying to not lose the momentum while you increase even more an epic chain of explosions.

It has a perfectly crafted level design, that like Nintendo‚Äôs most beloved classics, works on a two-dimensional level of complexity. There is a first layer in the game that makes it instantly pleasant to play only to be absorbed in its universe, being an experience close to meditation and with a main mechanic that is instantly fun. And then comes with its second layer of complexity, because the better you learn its level structure, scoring system and enemies patterns, the more you can improve your runs in a competitive way. In each run you can feel your progress, how you have a better knowledge of the game rules every time. At the end, destroying the enemies becomes an instinctive reflex skill.

Particle Mace is a game almost eternal. Its three main infinite modes are truly differentiated among them. Each mode has a completely different layout with a diverse range of challenges that can immensely alter the gameplay. And every layout is in a constant change. The more you score, the more new elements are included. Its level of creativity is incredible, slowly introducing new ideas, patterns and obstacles.

And then you have a glorious 150 missions mode that constantly amazes you with new design ideas, new menaces, new rules. This mode exhibits a level of ingenuity in its construction that is on par with the constant sense of surprise and novelty found in each of the levels of Super Mario Galaxy. With Particle Mace, Andy Wallace reveals himself as one of the better videogame designers of his generation.

And all of this is embraced with one of the most beautiful and evocative abstract worlds seen since Tetsuya Mizoguchi‚Äôs Rez. The game is enveloped by a special sense of loneliness, an intense feeling of melancholy and introspection that can let us spend hundred of hours in it, while we‚Äôre absorbed in a universe constructed via suspended and ethereal backgrounds. A feeling that is intensified thanks to a hypnotic soundtrack that rises in a perfect crescendo to highlight the most action packed moments.

Particle Mace is one of these games that like Rez years before, makes that you couldn‚Äôt conceive a single hard work day that not end in feeling for a mere instant its abstract beauty while you are immersed in the still of the night. Captivating your soul and showing you the true meaning of the expression videogames as an art form.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PARTICLE MACE is a frantic blast of space trash smash'emup action where you will spin it to win it. The elegant movements of your ship are like a ballet of geometrical anarchy. In the same way that games like Nidhogg bring the local multiplayer insanity to the platforming brawler genres, PARTICLE MACE brings the same level of abstract and chaotic couch co-op to the action arcade genre.

The controls and the physics revolving around your cluster of tethered space garbage really hit the nail on the head. There's a serious feeling of weight to the mace you're swinging around as you swerve to each side trying to get it's momentum going, and when you do it feels very natural. There are different ships of different speeds to accommodate each and every play style, ranging from the super slow ship with a large and effective particle mace to the extremely fast and speedy ship with a longer and harder to control mace.

Getting into the groove of the game is a very zen-like experience, becoming lost in the motions of your ship weaving in and out of clusters of asteroids. The movement of your chosen ship feels incredibly fluid and responsive, giving you the edge you need to navigate through the narrowest of passages in-between asteroids and your intimidating red foes.

The multiplayer co-op is where PARTICLE MACE really shines as it isn't just the simple addition of new players on the screen, but features some discoverable techniques like the combining of Maces or the revival of fallen teammates floating by helplessly which will require the full coordination of each participating player.

Even in it's early stages there's already a whole slew of really great modes and options you would expect from a polished full release, including the progressive mission mode which dishes out a series of unique and increasingly harder tasks to take on  that will earn you new ships, √† la Luftrausers. Although seemingly simple on the surface, PARTICLE MACE is a huge game with incredible polish and an almost infinite learning curve, making this one hell of an addictive ride to pick up and play for the shortest bursts of play to the longest couch co-op jam sessions.

I don't usually write reviews, but I love this game. You know how sometimes you're just looking for a good, cheap game that you can sink your teeth into right away without having to think too much about it? A game that has an interesting new mechanic and is instantly addictive? This is that game. It takes about five seconds to learn the basics, and then it grabs you--that whole whip-the-mace-at-rocks-and-ships thing.

For those who don't know: Imagine chunks of space junk tethered (by bungie cords) to an agile spaceship. The trick is to, with a single thumbstick, use the ship's momentum and direction to fling those tethered chunks like a mace and pulverize asteroids and enemy ships. (Yes, there is a local, four-player muiltiplayer mode.) It's simply divine.

While it is inspired by arcade classics, it instantly sets itself apart. There's a whole lot of variety here for just a few bucks. This is that game you'll play as your warm-up for a marathon session of some bigger, grander game. Only...you'll probably look up after a few hours and realize that you spent all your time flinging the PARTICLE MACE.

WARNING: Like a lot of folks, I was disappointed about the lack of Steam Controller support. I'm glad I took the time to dig up my old Xbox 360 controller, but this omission is unfortunate.

Still, to quote Doug McKenzie: ...all in all
date: a good five dollars worth for me and my whole family.""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bias: I did the sounds for this game (not the music), and I'm friends with Andy (the dev). While my clocked hours may not seem significant, trust me when I say I've played this game A LOT outside of steam.

PARTICLE MACE is an arcade game that you can pick up and play in seconds. The only input is movement. That's it. You only press buttons in the menu. This makes for an easy to learn, difficult to master experience... gamer or not. It's great to play alone, and even better to play with friends.

Part of why I love this game is how refined the movement is. PM doesn't try to be anything other than a rad arcade game. It doesn't stretch itself too thin, choosing instead to be a surgical strike of awesome. You want to top the charts on the high score list, or you want to destroy your friends by elegantly weaving through every obstacle and hitting that PERFECT swing of the mace into lesser players. You won't find branching dialogue, super crazy 3D graphics, or dozens of intricate maps. What you will find is an environment you think you've mastered, only to realize (either by high scores or deathmatch) that you aren't anywhere near as great as you thought you were. Killed by a stray asteroid? You failed. Dodge it next time. This is what PARTICLE MACE is.

The ships all change the way you move / play in a meaningful and drastic way, which really made me eager to unlock and try them all. The music is amazing (again, friends with the composer), and the game is really nice to look at. The background is awesome to look at. While it can be played on damn near everything, I prefer the controller. If you live in the NYC area, track down the actual arcade cabinet for the best experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Particle Mace has a bullet hell shooter vibe, but also has a much stronger feeling of flow / getting into a groove than shooters typically do. The game feels great and is very satisfying to play. The controls are polished and intuitive, the physics of the mace weapon are easy to learn, but there's clearly a high skill ceiling for tricks and techniques. Enemies, obstables, and level have simple and easy to read designs, very well done.

In spite of how easy the game is to learn the missions (meta objectives) add a surpising amount of depth. For instance, some require you to limit movement or avoid killing things for a period of time. This challenges you to alter your style of play to complete a goal and think tactically rather than turn off your brain.

I can't say how the game feels over a longer period time but the core mechanics are very well polished. You can pick this up and play it for just a few minutes and get quite a bit of enjoyment out of it. I feel like the psychological rewards in the core game loop are capable of making longer play sessions enjoyable too. I definitely recommended this if you like physics-based gameplay and/or bullet hell shooter types, and don't suffer from epilepsy.

Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Particle Mace with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.

Particle Mace was a wonderful surprise; with a blend of asteroid/geometry wars aesthetic and Hammerfight combat, my first session was 3 or 4 hours of ‚Äújust one more try‚Äù.

If you have never played Hammerfight, you‚Äôre not missing out on much but that is besides the point. The game controls just like every other twin stick shooter out there but instead of using the other stick to pick a direction to fire, you must master inertia to swing around a handful of tethered particles in order to strike down the enemies. There are several ship variants to unlock and each handle markedly differently but all feel wonderful and responsive to pilot. In addition, there are also many modifiers applied to the the tethers in the ‚ÄúMission‚Äù mode to mix things up a bit.

On the subject of modes, there are 4 total of which I have only dabbled in two of them. I didn‚Äôt try out coop or deathmatch but I spent extensive time with the arcade (survival) and mission modes. The arcade has 3 endless difficulties-easy, hard and asteroid only-and they scale remarkably well as time passes and you begin to rack the points up. The mission mode constantly cycles through objectives and conditions to meet and is a blast to work through. Unfortunately, this can get rather frustrating because you may get assigned 3 very conflicting quests at once and they each can hinder the others from being completed. It would be really nice to be able to pass on a mission temporarily when it‚Äôs causing trouble. However, Particle Mace is still a blast to play despite this quirk as the Arcade mode provides more than enough challenge and replayability.

I was honestly not expecting much booting it up, but I‚Äôm so glad to have discovered this little gem.

Eyo! This is my first review, but I'll try to be as informative as I can to try and help you make your decision of either to buy or not buy this game. :D

To buy or not to buy... that is the question.

FYI: I'm writing this only after having the game for one day... I actually just purchased it today.

Pros/Cons:

Pros:
-Cheap!
-Not a shooting game! (not sure if that's considered a pro, but just letting you know)
-The pro above this one rhymed
-Addicting
-150 missions
-Arcade-style (which I'm guessing you must like if you're even considering this game. :P)
-Many different unlockable ships with their own unique traits, try to collect 'em all!

Cons:
-Not really a multiplayer game (you can play in multiplayer but then you'd all have to be sitting in front of the same computer, and don't quote me on this but I'm 99% sure multiplayer requires a controller)
-No way to get rid of the border around the area where you're allowed to travel, meaning that you are always stuck in that little space.  There's no option for an unlimited world, so you are always stuck within the restraints of that border.  Just something that bugs me a little.  Just a little.
-The soundtrack isn't included with the game.  You have to purchase it separately.  This is my first time encountering this so I'm not sure if it's common practice, but something I didn't like.
-Graphics are well... arcade-like.  But it's an arcade style game, so...

----------
Overview
----------

You're a small, tiny ship stuck in the middle of space.  You have no weapons except some orange trash particles attached by strings to your ship.  You must maneuver your ship around to get the trash particles to hit the asteroids and other enemies.  Your enemies are the red shapes, which, unlike the asteroids, will actually aim for you.  In mission mode, you can try and complete various challenges.  In arcade mode, there are no preset challenges, so you just try to top your previous high score.  There are 3 different difficulties, 4 if you count tutorial mode: Easy, Hard, and Asteroid.  Easy and hard are pretty self-explanatory, while asteroids has no enemies in it, only asteroids.  There's also 2 different multiplayer modes, but I can't say much for those because I'm unable to play them due to a lack of controllers.  Overall, I would definitely reccomend this game to anyone with time to spare and prefers a strategy, arcade style game over a violent shooting game.  If what you've been reading sounds like your cup of tea, then I'd definitely reccomend you pick this game up.  It's worth the money, although I did get mine for 53 cents as it is on a 92% discount as of this moment (39 cents for the game, 14 cents for the soundtrack).

Thanks for reading my first ever game review! :D Hope I helped you with your decision.  If you have any questions, just let me know.

reviewText:
I felt awful after about 10 minutes. I felt that I had failed as a gamer for not having known this existed till I got it for ¬£0.13.

If you like twin stick shooters you will like this single stick swinger". Take an asteroids/arena shooter and use what skills you've learned from more traditional games and flail around pressing buttons not really getting it. A few more deaths and it's sinking in and before long you are tearing around as you would in most shooters but applying as best you can a really cool and totally fresh feeling mechanic.

The long story short is you are dragging balls behind your ship on stretchy string and you play a hectic game of homicidal swingball. The mission structure is really cool. You are tasked with 3 objectives per life
date: like "get a multi kill in 12 seconds" and "get 4 kills without destroying any asteroids". If you die
recommended: the missions you didn't complete roll over and the ones you did get replaced. There isn't a great deal of variance in backdrops as far I could see but this kind of thing doesn't need vajazzling. It really thrives on the mechanics and if you are the kind of person that likes blowing stuff up and scoring points
hoursPlayed: you would be the mental not to get it."

As I said earlier, it's a fun concept but it needs a BIT of polishing/some bugfixes and - well - doesn't seem like the developer plans to do any

reviewText: Cheap, creative, and most importantly, it's fun, buy it.

First of all, I played this game on my netbook at 1024x600 resolution and it worked perfectly (which is handy to know because most developers never specify the minimum resolution for their games). I also used a mouse rather than a gamepad. I suspect a gamepad might be better, but the mouse is perfectly usable too.

I initially didn't like this game. I started in the arcade mode and found it way too difficult to reliably control the swinging action of the trash particles that you use to smash the astroids and ships (especially without swinging myself into something else). Unlike the classic Asteroids game where you generally have plenty of space to move, it's a very crowded universe and it just made it frustrating to be able to build up momentum.

However, the lure of trading cards made me persevere and I tried the missions. These were much more accessible than the arcade mode since it gave me just three small goals to try at a time. Rather than just keep swinging around wildly in a vain attempt to clear the level (impossible), I had to use some finesse to complete a mission and this really improved my experience. Sometimes I had to go racing around to get to certain points within a time limit so that rather than smashing the asteroids I just weaved around them like Han Solo. Other times I had to only destroy a certain number of the enemy, which can be tricky when they all group together. I learnt to let them chase me and trick them into ramming my trash. Other missions have you staying within a small area for a certain time, or destroying a particulary fast enemy ship.

I still have a fair way to go in the missions, but I know that I will keep this game around once I have finished it just to have quick sessions when I find myself with a bit of spare time. Just for the sake of this review, I tried playing the arcade mode again to see how I fare this time. It was much better than my first attempt. The skills I had learnt in the missions really paid off in the arcade mode. Rather than spinning around wildly, I could do surgical strikes on any asteroid or ship that took my fancy. I am so glad I spent the time building the skills to be able to find this game such a blast!

Now if you don't mind, I have just unlocked a new ship so I have to go run it through its paces.

This game is surprisingly addictive!  I've only been playing the missions, so no multiplayer for me - would be nice if there was some form of online multiplayer though!

The controls are simple and feel really smooth (I use a controller).  The missions get suitably more challenging and often affect the gameplay style as they affect the environment which keeps things varied and interesting.  I really like the different ships you can get (I've unlocked 2 on top of the starter ship so far) and I like the fact that some are better for some missions than others, meaning I often switch between them rather than finding that one is too OP and using that all the time.

The only problem I had was that when you kill an enemy, the screen jolts for split second and you get a +10 on the screen (or whatever number it is) which is fine and feels really good when you kill an enemy, but when there were a fair number of enemies being killed, it sometimes made my ship a bit harder to control as it was constantly stopping and the +10s were blocking my view!

I've played around 4 hrs and have completed around 130/150 challenges so I'd guess the missions part lasts around 5 total. There's also an arcade mode and multiplayer (co-op and versus) which I have yet to try.  It's a really fun game and wonderfully frustrating at times, so pick it up, play it.  Who needs sleep anyway?

There are about 8 different ships you can unlock, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, they are pretty evenly balanced. The three different modes keep you pretty busy, with arcade ranging from easy to hard, to a special asteroids-only mode where there are no enemies, but that only makes it harder. There are 150 different challenges in challenge mode and some of them are pretty creative, such as avoiding the black hole, or destroying X amount of enemies with only two particles.\nSurprizingly enough, I love the soundtrack for this game. When you first jump into the game is has a calm, 16-bit sounding rhythm, but slowly speeds up the longer you survive, and becomes frantic as the map itself tries to kill you. I went ahead and bought the soundtrack with the game, and I am not disappointed.\nSince this game is currently $0.19, I suggest buying it right now before it goes back up to $9.99. In comparing games and game systems, the refrain Graphics don't matter
date:
is typically just the fallback cry of the partisan whose favoured game or system has demonstrably inferior graphics.  Particle Mace is one of the rare games that proves the phrase correct.

Graphically, Particle Mace is an obvious direct descendant of the original vectored Asteroids, just prettied up a little.  Instead of pivot-and-shoot gameplay, however, your gunless ship battles by dragging little objects around on tethers, and using inertia to swing them around.  It's a fairly simple concept, but the game keeps it from getting stale too quickly by gradually introducing variant ships with slightly different performance characteristics, and missions (challenges, really) that provide twists on the core gameplay.

Particle Mace is a simple but addictive game.  Part of the secret of the addictiveness is that the game gradually gets harder, but is scrupulously fair.  It gives that one more try" feeling because
recommended: when you die -- and you die a lot -- the death always feels like your fault.  I've yet to have a death in this game feel like the game cheated or presented an impossible situation; I always get the sense that if I'd only played a little bit better

Very fun. The concept of the game is simple, you fly around dragging a bunch of weights that are smashed into enemies while trying not to crash into obstacles. It reminds me of Hammerfight quite a bit, with a dash geometry wars thrown in. It's incredibly satisfying to control, especially when you accomplish something tricky. There are a number of different ships with their own quirks and features, I really enjoyed the differences they each provided, especially in the multiplayer versus. They're not really balanced, but that hardly matters when you're playing by yourself or with friends.

No online, but local multiplayer is pretty solid if you've got people around and multiple gamepads. There aren't very many maps, but they're dynamic and faily distinct. The game also slowed down quite a bit in multiplayer as players moved apart and the game had to zoom out. This was on my laptop however, which is nothing close to a powerhouse, but still suggests some optimization issues.

I don't think I'd recommend the game without a controller, I just can't imagine fluidly controlling the ships without one. Fortunately, it's been friendly with all types that I've tried (360 and logitech).

If nothing else, it's great arcade time waster.
